results.title: Un Jardin public
results.brief_description: In the Square Gambetta in Paris a little boy’s imagination brings a statue to life. There follows a transformation scene and in an imaginary park Marcel Marceau acts out in mime all the habitues of the park - the nursemaids, the young lovers, the policemen, and old men. His impersonations range from the faintly amusing to the maudlin, but Marceau’s many admirers will doubtless enjoy this film.

results.title: Un Innocent = an Innocent Man
results.brief_description:
Albert and Monique work in a plush hotel, respectively as night watchman and chambermaid. Monique is having an affair with Bob, the hotel barman. In order to finance their plan to elope to Biarritz and get rid of Albert, they set him up to burgle the room of one of the hotel guest. Albert is caught and the case is assigned to Judge Massot. During an interview with Judge Massot, Albert escapes and runs back home where he barricades himself with his children. As the police starts the siege of the house, Judge Massot decides to step in and talk Albert out of doing an even bigger mistake.

Credits: Producer, Jean Gauthier ; director, Nadine Trintigant ; writers, Patrick Modiano ; photography, William Lubtchansky ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Simone Signoret, Didier Haudepin, Jean-Claude Dauphin, Michel Vitold, Philippe Leotard, Juliet Berto, Etienne Chicot, Maurice Garrel, Pierre Vernier, Francois Perrot, Marie Trintignant.

results.title: Un Inconnu Nomme Eiffel
results.brief_description:
Gustave Eiffel was afraid that his famous tower would overshadow his other accomplishments. This short film sets out to shed light on a very prolific international engineering career which included the building of railway bridges, viaducts and the metal frame of the Statue of Liberty.

Credits: Director, Joan Laskoff ; photography, Jacques Mercanton ; music, Betty Willemetz.

results.title: Un Homme Qui Dort = a Man Who Sleeps
results.brief_description:
A student refuses to carry on with his studies and decides to live ‘in neutral time’ or at the limit of schizophrenia. Reference: Film Index International.

Credits: Director, Bernard Queysanne ; writers, Bernard Queysanne, Georges Perec ; photography, Bernard Zitzermann ; music, Philippe Drogoz, Eugenie Kuffler.
Cast: Jacques Spiesser, Ludmila Mikael.

results.title: Un Grand Patron
results.brief_description:
Doctor Delage is so dedicated to his work that he is out of tune with everything else, including wife, family and assistants. Through his encounter with a young orphan he is soon drawn to reassess his values and priorities in life and to rediscover is humanity.

Credits: Producer, Andre Paulve ; director, Yves Ciampi ; writers, Pierre Very, Yves Ciampi ; photography, Marcel Grignon ; Joseph Kosma.
Cast: Pierre Fresnay, Renee Devillers, Jean-Claude Pascal, Claire duhamel, Maurice Ronet, Claude Nicot.

results.title: Un Enfant Dans la Foule = a Child in the Crowd
results.brief_description:
In 1937, Paul is a boarder in a religious institution. He suffers greatly from being separated from his mother and lets his school grades slip. During the Occupation, he becomes the pet of German soldiers, running errands for them. Later, he helps the Resistance, and when the Americans come to stay, he is really in his element with them. The films chronicles Paul’s attempts to fit in and connect with an authority figure.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Gerard Blain ; writers, Gerard Blain, Michel Perez ; photography, Emmanuel Machuel ; music, Jean Schwarz.
Cast: Jean-Francois Cimino, Cesar Chauveau, Annie Kovacs, Claire Treille, Jean Bertal.

results.title: Un Drole de Paroissien = Thank Heaven for Small Favors
results.creator_credit: Jean-Pierre Mocky, Jerome Goulven and Henri Diamant-Berger
results.brief_description:
The Lachaunay family, high-born aristocrats, have fallen on hard times and must resort to stripping off the doors and panelling of their Paris appartment to use as firewood. They are also threatened with eviction, but never waver from their conviction that they were born not to work. One of them, the ultra-religious Georges resorts to stealing money from offertory boxes. This is a wonderfully provocative and anti-clerical comedy, served by a subtle and humourous performance by Bourvil.

Credits: Producers, Henri Diamant-Berger, Jerome Goulven ; director, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; writer, Alain Moury, Michel Servin ; photography, Leonce-Henri Burel ; music, Joseph Kosma ; art direction, Pierre Thyberhein.
Cast: Bourvil, Jean Poiret, Francis Blanche, Jean Yonnel, Jean Tissier, Solange Certain, Denise Peronne, Veronique Nordey, Jean Galland, Bernard Lavallette.

results.title: Un Dimanche a la Campagne = A Sunday in the Country
results.brief_description:
In 1912, Monsieur Ladmiral, 76, lives alone in his home on the outskirts of Paris. He is a talented painter who will not adapt to the new Impressionist style. As happens most Sundays, he awaits the visit of his son and family. It promises to be a Sunday like many others, full of politeness and affection. The sudden arrival of Irene, Mr. Ladmiral’s daughter disrupts the monotony of the day. Young and emancipated, Irene stirs up the laughter of the children, the anger of Mr. Ladmiral’s son and the old man’s nostalgia. The film contains many references to French painters such as Bonnard and Vuillard, as well as to Jean Renoir’s ‘Une Partie de Campagne’. Awards: Cannes Film Festival 1984: Best mise-en-scene; French Academy of Cinema (Cesar) 1984: Best Actress Sabine Azema, Best Cinematography Bruno de Keyzer, Best Screenplay Adaptation Colo Tavernier O’Hagan and Bertrand Tavernier; New-York Film Critics Circle Award: Best Foreign Language Film.

Credits: Producers, Alain Sarde, Bertrand Tavernier ; director, Bertrand Tavernier; writers, Betrand Tavernier, Colo Tavernier O’Hagan ; photography, Bruno de Keyzer ; music, Louis Ducreux, Marc Perronne, Gabriel Faure ; costume design, Yvonne Sassino
Cast: Louis Ducreux, Sabine Azema, Michel Aumont, Genevieve Mnich, Monique Chaumette.

results.title: Un Chien andalou
results.brief_description: A surrealistic film using symbolic objects and settings designed by Salvador Dali. The film was a collaboration between Bunuel and Dali over 3 days and shot in 2 weeks. A series of seemingly unrelated images are unified by their power to shock. The famed opening sequence was left out some releases by censors. Enthusiastically received by Paris surrealists, the film saw Bunuel and Dali being recognised by their peers, and it still enjoys its innovative arthouse status. Censorship restriction: Suitable only for adults.
